Title: Menstruation, Sanitary Products, and School Attendance: Evidence from a Randomized Evaluation
The Labor Market Returns to Cognitive and Noncognitive Ability: Evidence from the Swedish Enlistment
Data Comments: As our data contains sensitive information on individual outcomes (such as health status), Swedish law requires users of the data to hold a permission from an Ethical Review Board (“Centrala Etikprövningsnämnden”). This implies that it is not possible for us to make our data directly available online. However, researchers interested in obtaining our data could themselves apply for permission from the Ethical Review Board. The website of the Ethical Review Board (http://www.epn.se/start/startsida.aspx) contains information on how to apply. The cost of applying for permission from an ethics board is 5000 SEK (about 700 dollars). The Ethical Review Board does currently only allow applications in Swedish. Having obtained permission to use the data, the actual matching is done by Statistics Sweden

Confidential county-level abortion provider data from The Alan Guttmacher Institute: "We acquired confidential county-level AGI data on the number of abortion facilities (providers)

Title: Do Social Connections Reduce Moral Hazard? Evidence from the New York City Taxi Industry
Data Comments:
"To obtain these data, I contacted Andrew Salkin, First Deputy Commission at the TLC, and requested data on driver characteristics, owner characteristics, medallion characteristics, and driving outcomes. I then signed a proprietary data sharing agreement with the TLC regarding maintaining data confidentiality. The TLC then ran queries on the main TLC internal databases to generate the data files above, which I picked up in person at the TLC office at 40 Rector Street,
New York, NY."

Title: Health Capital and the Prenatal Environment: The Effect of Ramadan Observance during Pregnancy
Data Comments:
Both international IPUMS and Michigan Department of Community Health. We thus purchased Michigan’s births data for 1989-2005 in 2007.1
 Michigan referred to these
records as: “Live birth files, Michigan residents 1989-2005.” At the time, we were charged
$2,550 ($150 per birth year). The mailing address for obtaining these data is:
Michigan Department of Community Health
Vital Records and Health Data Development Section
201 Townsend St., 2nd floor
PO Box 30691
Lansing, MI 48909
In practice, the most useful contact for obtaining these data is for Michael Beebe
(BeebeM@michigan.gov). To him we provided three completed application documents:
1. A$“data$files$request$form”.$$A"blank"copy"of"this"form"follow"immediately"follows"this"
summary;
2. A$“Michigan$IRB$Review$Application”.$A"blank"copy"of"this"form"follow"immediately"
follows"this"summary;
3. A$freeBstanding$study$protocol.
In the IRB application, we requested exception from IRB review under section 46.101 b(4)
